faq_page.hero_subtitle: Find answers to common questions about IHSS, our services, and the benefits application process.

q1.q: What is the difference between SSI and SSDI?
q1.a: SSI (Supplemental Security Income) is a needs-based program for people with limited income and resources who are aged, blind, or disabled. SSDI (Social Security Disability Insurance) is based on your work history and the Social Security taxes you've paid. You may qualify for one or both programs depending on your situation. We can help you determine which benefits you're eligible for.

q2.q: How much does your service cost?
q2.a: We offer a free initial consultation to assess your situation. Our fees vary depending on the services you need. For SSDI cases, many representatives work on a contingency basis — meaning you only pay if you win your case. We'll explain all costs upfront before any work begins so there are never any surprises.

q3.q: What languages do you offer services in?
q3.a: We provide full services in English, Spanish, Farsi (Persian), and Tagalog (Filipino). All of our documents, consultations, and communications are available in these four languages. If you need support in another language, contact us and we'll do our best to accommodate you.

q4.q: How do I know if I qualify for SSI?
q4.a: To qualify for SSI, you must be aged 65 or older, blind, or disabled, AND have limited income and resources. For 2026, the resource limit is $2,000 for individuals and $3,000 for couples. Income limits vary by state. California has higher SSI payment amounts than the federal minimum. We can evaluate your specific situation to determine eligibility.

q5.q: How long does the SSI application process take?
q5.a: The SSI application process typically takes 3 to 6 months for an initial decision. If your claim is denied and you need to appeal, the process can take longer — sometimes 12 to 24 months through all appeal levels. We work to ensure your initial application is as strong as possible to improve your chances of first-time approval.

q6.q: What qualifies as a disability for SSDI?
q6.a: The Social Security Administration defines disability as a medical condition that prevents you from performing substantial gainful activity (SGA) and is expected to last at least 12 months or result in death. This includes both physical and mental conditions. The SSA maintains a 'Blue Book' listing of qualifying impairments, but you can also qualify if your combined conditions prevent you from working.

q7.q: How many work credits do I need for SSDI?
q7.a: Generally, you need 40 work credits for SSDI, with 20 of those credits earned in the last 10 years. You can earn up to 4 credits per year. Younger workers may qualify with fewer credits. For example, if you become disabled before age 24, you may only need 6 credits earned in the 3 years before your disability began.

q8.q: What happens if my disability claim is denied?
q8.a: If your claim is denied, you have 60 days to appeal. The appeals process has four levels: Reconsideration, hearing before an Administrative Law Judge (ALJ), Appeals Council review, and Federal Court review. Statistics show that many claims are approved at the ALJ hearing level. Our appeals support service guides you through each level with thorough preparation.

q9.q: Can I work while receiving disability benefits?
q9.a: Yes, with limitations. SSDI has a Trial Work Period (TWP) that allows you to test your ability to work for 9 months without losing benefits. After the TWP, you enter a 36-month Extended Period of Eligibility. SSI has different rules — your benefits are reduced based on your earnings but not immediately eliminated. We can explain how working affects your specific benefits.

q10.q: What documents do I need to apply?
q10.a: You'll typically need: Social Security card or number, birth certificate, medical records and doctor contact information, work history for the past 15 years, tax returns or W-2 forms, bank statements (for SSI), and any documentation of your medical conditions. We help you gather and organize all required documents to ensure nothing is missing from your application.

q11.q: How long does the entire process take from start to finish?
q11.a: The timeline varies by case. An initial application decision typically takes 3 to 6 months. If approved on the first attempt, you could receive benefits within that timeframe. If denied and you need to appeal, the process can extend to 12-24 months or more, depending on your local hearing office's backlog. We work diligently to move your case forward as quickly as possible.

q12.q: Do I need to see the Social Security Administration in person?
q12.a: Not necessarily. Many aspects of the application can be handled online or by phone. However, some situations may require an in-person visit to your local SSA office. If a Consultative Examination (CE) is requested, you'll need to attend that medical appointment. We help you prepare for any required meetings or examinations.

q13.a: IHSS is a California program that provides in-home care services to eligible aged, blind, or disabled individuals who cannot safely live at home without assistance. Services include housecleaning, meal preparation, laundry, personal care, accompaniment to medical appointments, and protective supervision. IHSS is funded by Medi-Cal and administered by each county.

q14.q: What is protective supervision for IHSS?
q14.a: Protective supervision is an IHSS service for recipients who are non-self-directing and need 24-hour supervision to prevent injury. It can provide up to 283 hours per month (compared to the standard 195-hour maximum for other services). Your doctor must complete a SOC 821 form certifying the need. Many initial requests are denied, but we have experience overturning these denials.

q15.a: The SOC 821 is the 'Physician's Report for IHSS Protective Supervision' form. Your doctor must complete it to support a request for protective supervision hours. The form asks the doctor to certify that the recipient is non-self-directing and at risk of injury without constant supervision. Under California Health & Safety Code 123114, your doctor cannot charge you for completing this form.

q16.q: How does the IHSS fair hearing process work?
q16.a: If you disagree with a county IHSS decision, you can request a State fair hearing within 90 days of receiving your Notice of Action. You can request the hearing online, by phone, or by mail. An Administrative Law Judge will review your case and issue a decision. If you request the hearing before the effective date of the action and ask for aid-paid-pending, your current services continue until the hearing decision.

q17.q: What is the maximum number of IHSS hours I can receive?
q17.a: The maximum number of IHSS hours varies by service category. For most services, the combined maximum is 283 hours per month (195 hours for domestic and related services plus up to 195 hours for personal care). If you qualify for protective supervision, you may receive up to 283 hours per month for that service alone. The actual hours authorized depend on your individual needs assessment.

q18.q: Can my doctor charge me for filling out IHSS forms?
q18.a: No. Under California Health and Safety Code Section 123114, healthcare providers cannot charge patients for completing forms required for government benefits programs, including IHSS. This applies to the SOC 821 (protective supervision), SOC 825 (plan of care), and other IHSS-related medical forms. If your doctor tries to charge you, inform them of this law.

q19.a: Aid-paid-pending means your current IHSS services continue at the existing level while your appeal is being processed. To qualify, you must request a fair hearing BEFORE the effective date listed on your Notice of Action and specifically request aid-paid-pending. This is critical — if you wait until after the effective date, your services may be reduced or terminated during the appeal process.

q20.q: What is an authorized representative for IHSS?
q20.a: An authorized representative is someone you designate to act on your behalf in IHSS matters, including at fair hearings. This requires completing form DPA 19 (for the hearing) or SOC 839 (for county interactions). We serve as authorized representatives for our clients — handling communications, preparing evidence, and representing you at hearings. For court proceedings, we connect you with qualified attorneys.

q21.q: What is the difference between form DPA 19 and SOC 839?
q21.a: The DPA 19 (Authorized Representative form) is used to designate someone to represent you at a State fair hearing before an Administrative Law Judge. The SOC 839 (IHSS Recipient Designation of Authorized Representative) is used to authorize someone to interact with the county IHSS office on your behalf. You may need both forms if we are representing you at the county level and at a hearing.

protective_page.hero_subtitle: Understanding protective supervision, maximum hours, and how to fight denials.
protective_page.what_is_text: Protective supervision is an IHSS service category for recipients who are non-self-directing due to a mental impairment or mental illness. It provides observation and supervision to prevent injury, harm, or accidents. Unlike other IHSS services, protective supervision can authorize up to 24 hours per day of care.
protective_page.soc821_text: To qualify for protective supervision, your doctor must complete the SOC 821 (Physician's Report for IHSS Protective Supervision). This form asks the doctor to certify that the recipient is non-self-directing and at risk of injury without constant supervision.
protective_page.soc825_text: The SOC 825 is used to document the plan for protective supervision coverage, including who will provide supervision and during what hours.
protective_page.doctor_charge_title: Can My Doctor Charge Me for IHSS Forms?
protective_page.doctor_charge_text: No. Under California Health and Safety Code Section 123114, your doctor cannot charge you for completing forms required for government benefit programs. This includes the SOC 821, SOC 825, and all other IHSS-related medical forms.
protective_page.denial_reasons_title: Common Denial Reasons & How to Respond
protective_page.denial_response_1: Gather detailed documentation from doctors showing specific examples of non-self-directing behavior.
protective_page.denial_response_2: Work with the doctor to provide specific medical evidence and behavioral examples.
protective_page.denial_reason_3: County claims other services are sufficient
protective_page.denial_response_3: Document incidents showing current services don't prevent risk of injury.
protective_page.evidence_3: Incident reports or hospital records showing past injuries
protective_page.evidence_5: Letters from therapists, social workers, or other professionals
protective_page.evidence_6: Caregiver testimony about daily supervision needs
protective_page.cta_text: We've helped hundreds of families secure protective supervision hours. Let us review your case.

fair_hearing_page.hero_subtitle: Everything you need to know about requesting and preparing for your State fair hearing.
fair_hearing_page.how_to_request_title: How to Request a Fair Hearing
fair_hearing_page.how_to_request_text: You can request a State fair hearing three ways: online through the California Department of Social Services website, by phone at 1-800-952-5253, or by mail. You must file within 90 days of receiving your Notice of Action.
fair_hearing_page.deadline_text: You have exactly 90 days from the date you receive your Notice of Action to request a hearing. If you file BEFORE the effective date of the county's action AND request aid-paid-pending, your current services will continue while your appeal is processed.
fair_hearing_page.aid_pending_text: Aid-paid-pending is your right to continue receiving your current IHSS services at the same level while your appeal is being processed. You must request it when you file your hearing request, and you must file BEFORE the effective date on your Notice of Action. This is critical — waiting too long means losing your services during the appeal.
fair_hearing_page.what_to_expect_title: What to Expect at Your Hearing
fair_hearing_page.what_to_expect_text: Your hearing will be conducted by an Administrative Law Judge (ALJ) from the California Department of Social Services. The hearing may be held in person, by phone, or by video. You'll have the opportunity to present evidence, call witnesses, and make arguments for why the county's decision should be overturned.
fair_hearing_page.representative_title: Having a Representative at Your Hearing
fair_hearing_page.representative_text: You have the right to be represented at your hearing. We serve as your authorized representative — preparing your case, organizing evidence, and presenting arguments on your behalf. To authorize us, you'll need to complete a DPA 19 form.
fair_hearing_page.dpa19_text: The DPA 19 authorizes someone to represent you at a State fair hearing. The SOC 839 authorizes someone to interact with the county IHSS office on your behalf. You may need both forms depending on your situation.
fair_hearing_page.prep_1: Copy of your Notice of Action
fair_hearing_page.prep_6: Any prior assessments or care plans
fair_hearing_page.compliance_note: We serve as your authorized representative at State fair hearings. For cases that may proceed to Superior Court or require formal legal representation, we connect you with qualified disability and elder law attorneys in your area.
fair_hearing_page.cta_text: Don't go in unprepared. Let our team build your case and represent you.
